nodes.text: Automatically identifying and re-prioritizing input-sensitive "incubative" instructions via MINPSID increases selective instruction duplication (SID) SDC coverage and mitigates coverage loss when programs run with multiple inputs
Existing SID evaluations that select instructions based on a single reference input can suffer large loss of SDC coverage when the protected program is executed with different inputs

A small subset of instructions, called incubative instructions, have near-zero measured SDC probability on the reference input but much higher SDC probability on other inputs and are responsible for most of the SDC coverage loss

MINPSID identifies incubative instructions using static CFG analysis, a genetic algorithm guided input search that generates weighted CFGs per input, per-instruction fault injection on selected inputs, and re-prioritizes incubative instructions by updating their benefit to the observed upper bounds before knapsack selection and code transformation for duplication
MINPSID mitigates the loss of SDC coverage across multiple inputs compared to state-of-the-art SID, producing more conservative and more predictable expected coverage

Preliminary fault injection experiments on 11 HPC benchmarks show average SDC coverage under existing SID dropped from 96.12% to 58.76% across multiple inputs, with up to 100% loss in Kmeans and on average 37.58% of inputs causing coverage loss per benchmark

Analysis method to identify incubative instructions: collect instructions causing SDCs under reference input and under many other inputs, then select instructions that are non-overlapping (no SDC with reference input but cause SDCs on other inputs) and whose measured benefit shifts from near zero into high-percentiles across inputs
Characterization evidence: incubative instructions account for on average 15.79% of instructions per program (range 6.20% to 32.09%) and are responsible for at least 97% of observed SDC coverage loss

MINPSID implements a genetic algorithm input search with mutation and crossover, using a fitness based on average Euclidean distance between indexed weighted CFG lists to prioritize inputs that produce distinct execution paths
Per-input dynamic profiling constructs weighted CFGs by counting edge or basic-block execution frequencies and converts them into indexed lists for computing fitness and distinguishing inputs

Fault injection methodology: LLVM-level single-bit-flip injections using LLFI; per-instruction SDC probabilities measured with 100 injections per static instruction per input and program-level SDC probability measured with 1000 injections per input

Evaluation results: MINPSID reduces average percentage of inputs that cause SDC coverage loss from 37.58% (baseline SID) to 8.36%; MINPSID mitigates 97% of the coverage loss averaged over benchmarks and protection levels; expected coverage produced by MINPSID is more conservative

Additional findings: MINPSID identifies 45.60% more incubative instructions than a random input search within the time budget and takes on average 63.71 minutes (one-time compilation cost) versus 3.87 minutes for baseline SID preparation

Assumptions and fault model: focus on transient processor computing component faults (pipeline stages, flip-flops, functional units), single transient bit flips, ignore memory/cache faults assumed protected by ECC and control logic/instruction encoding faults

Limitations and threats: MINPSID increases one-time analysis cost and shares performance overhead variance across inputs with SID; evaluation uses LLVM-level FI and a selected set of benchmarks which may affect generality; mitigation of performance overhead variance is future work
